loans.name: Merveille Plus Group

texts.en:
Dieu Donné is the chairman of a community bank named “Merveille Plus”, which is composed of 15 micro entrepreneurs. They are united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC, with the goal of developing their businesses.

Dieu Donné started his business in 1991, selling miscellaneous goods. Today he operates a general boutique. He is 39 years old, married, and has a seven-year-old son who attends school. Dieu Donné is happy to be part of one of Hope’s groups that he joined in 2010. His business has been reinforced through the seven different loans he received, and then repaid them correctly. His store generates a profit of about $110 each week.
 
He intends to use the next loan to increase the inventory of his business by buying items for resale in the store.  In order to increase the profit and diversify his business, he will add beverages. His dream is to someday open a soft drink store. 

Dieu Donné sells in the north eastern area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: to purchase the store's items for resale in order to increase the profit.

loans.name: Jesús El Salvador Group

texts.es:
La Alcancía Comunal “Jesús el Salvador” tiene 04 meses trabajando con el Programa – Prosperidad es un grupo conformado por 07 socios responsables y empeñosos.  
Janeth es la tesorera del grupo, cargo que ha llevado con responsabilidad, ella tiene 35 años de edad es casada y tiene 03 hijos que en la actualidad depende de ellos. Janeth empezó vendiendo queques, poco a poco fue teniendo más clientes y sus pedidos aumentaban, es por ello que decidió comprarse un horno eléctrico donde le permitiera  elaborar sus queques con facilidad, Janeth se siente feliz con su negocio ya que aparte de obtener ganancias, también  es lo que le gusta hacer,  también trabaja conjuntamente con su esposo vendiendo productos naturales, gracias a dichas actividades ha podido dales una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. El deseo de  Janeth es de tener su propia pastelería donde pueda exhibir sus productos ya que solo lo hace ambulatoriamente. Ella  solicito el préstamo para seguir invirtiendo en su negocio comprando al por mayor insumos como harina, azúcar, leche, y también productos naturales. La Alcancía Comunal “Jesús el Salvador” están muy agradecidos con la ayuda brindada.
texts.en:
The communal bank, "Jesús el Salvador" (Jesus the Savior) has worked with the Prosperidad program for 4 months.  This is a group made up of 7 responsible and hard-working members.

Janeth is the treasurer of the group, a position that she has carried out with responsibility.  She is 35 and married and has 3 children who are her dependents.  Janeth started selling cakes, and little by little she has gained more customers, and her orders have increased.  This is why she decided to buy an electric oven that let her make her cakes easily.  Janeth is happy with her business because in addition to earning an income, it's also what she likes to do.  She also works with her husband selling natural products, and thanks to these businesses, she has been able to give her family a better quality of life.  Janeth's wish is to have her own bakery where she can display her products because now she has to travel around to make her sales.  She requested the loan to continue investing in her business by buying a larger quantity of supplies like flour, sugar, milk, and natural products.  The communal bank, "Jesús el Salvador," is very grateful for the help that they have been offered.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, milk, and natural products.

loans.name: Merali

texts.es: La señora Merali es una fémina trabajadora y emprendedora de 31 años de edad. Ella se dedica a la venta de comida desde hace 4 años con uno ahorros empezó ella sola en la actualidad cuenta con 7 trabajadores y un venta mayor. Ella con el crédito comprara productos para el negocio en especial granos básicos, carne, verduras, leña…etc.
texts.en: Señora Merali is a hard-working and enterprising woman, age 31. She has sold food for four years, and started this business on her own with her own savings. She now has seven employees and higher sales. With this loan she will purchase products for her business, especially basic grains, meat, vegetables, firewood, etc.

loans.use: to buy basic materials such as basic grains, meat, vegetables, firewood, etc.

loans.name: Benita De Los Angeles

texts.es:
Benita, se ha decidido por un nuevo préstamo el cual lo invertirá en su negocio, ya que quiere comprar más mercadería para la época de diciembre como: plátanos, guineos, yuca, zanahorias por medio de los préstamos a podido aumentar en sus ventas.
Ella está contento por los préstamos anteriores porque le han ayudado a  fortalecer su negocio y ha estado al día con sus cuotas y su familia está más estable económicamente, aunque en su ultimos pagos no fueron puntuales.
texts.en:
Benita has made up her mind to apply for a new loan, which she will invest in her business, since she wants to buy more merchandise for the December season. She will buy such items as bananas, small sweet bananas, yucca, and carrots. She has been able to increase her sales through the loans.

She is happy with her past loans because they have helped her strengthen her business and she has been up-to-date with her bills. Her family is more stable economically, even though her last payments were not on time.

loans.use: to buy bananas, little sweet bananas, yucca, and oil.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  ”JOSE CARLOS MARIATEGUI”;  El banco comunal se encuentra ubicado en el mismo corazón del valle sagrado de los inkas, en la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Sonia;  La socia tiene 31 años de edad, La socia es casada, La socia tiene 3 hijos 6, 3 y 7 meses de edad; la socia se dedica  al comercio minorista, la socia compra y vende frutas, la socia lleva al pampón a vender las frutas. La socia desea invertir el crédito en la compra de frutas al por mayor de los proveedores mayoristas, la socia compra y los reparte y vende directo también en el pampón que es una feria de venta de productos al por mayor y menor. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de fruta al por mayor .
La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete  a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de acuerdo al cronograma de pagos.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the “Jose Carlos Mariategui” communal bank. The bank is located in the sacred valley of the Inkas, in the province of Urubamba and in the department of Cusco.

The member is Sonia. She is 31 years old. She is married and has 3 children, who are 6 and 3 years old and 7 months. She sells retail merchandise—she buys and sells fruits and takes them to El Pampón to sell. She wants to use the loan to buy fruit at wholesale price from the wholesale providers. She buys them and sells them, and sells directly also in El Pampón, which is a wholesale and retail market. She is requesting the loan to buy fruit at wholesale price. 

Sonia appreciates the loan and pledges to make her payments in agreement with the timeframe for the repayments.

loans.use: to buy fruit at wholesale price.

loans.name: G.s. Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario que está conformado por Brenda Carolina y Cristian Isabel este grupo ya han tenido crédito con Fundación León 2000 en el cual han demostrado ser un grupo bastante unido y responsable. Brenda Carolina que es una de las integrantes se dedica a la comercialización de ropa, trastes plásticos y de vidrio y otros artículos en general. Aduce Brenda, que ha tenido éxitos recientes tal como fue la promoción de su hija de sexto grado de primaria. Su negocio ha mejorado, su nivel de vida también ya que las utilidades del negocio permiten tener más facilidades económicas. Actualmente esta solicitando crédito para comprar mercadería y poder seguir brindándole a sus clientes una variedad.
texts.en: This loan group is made of Brenda Carolina and Cristian Isabel.  They have already had a loan with Fundación León 2000 and have proven to be a rather united and responsible group.  Brenda Carolina, one of the members, works selling clothing, plastic and glass dishes, and other general items.  Brenda shares that she has had success recently, such as when her daughter graduated from sixth grade in primary school.  Her business has improved, and her level of life has also improved, since her business provides for her financial needs.  She is currently asking for a loan to buy merchandise to keep providing her customers with a good variety.

loans.use: buy merchandise

loans.name: Patricie

texts.en: Patricie is 54 years old. She is a widow with 15 children. Three of them go to school and the others don’t attend school due to financial problems. She sells sorghum, which she has been doing for the past 5 years. With this loan, she will buy more sorghum to sell. She plans to use the profits to buy home domestic products. In the future, she dreams of having a stock of foodstuffs.

loans.use: to buy sorghum

loans.name: Herney Alonso

texts.es:
Herney se encuentra casado y tiene 3 hijos de 2, 5 años y 3 meses de nacido, y para generar los ingresos para su hogar tiene una tienda general desde hace un tiempo corto en la cual ofrece productos de la canasta familiar. Gracias a sus buenas ventas, su tienda ha ido creciendo poco a poco, y así ir superando la gran dificultad de no contar con un capital para surtirla con mayor variedad de productos. Con el ánimo de atender mejor sus clientes y aumentar sus ventas, Herney busca que un préstamo le permita comprar un refrigerador y productos de la canasta familiar para ofrecer una mayor variedad de productos a sus clientes.

De esta manera sus ventas aumentarán considerablemente, pues podrá atender mejor a sus clientes y así hará que sus clientes aumenten cada día. Su sueño es tener un supermercado donde pueda generar empleo y desde el cual pueda ofrecer a sus hijos y esposa una mejor calidad de vida y una mejor estabilidad económica.

loans.use: Comprar un refrigerador y productos de la canasta familiar para ofrecer una mayor variedad de productos a sus clientes.

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en: Gertrude is married with five children and all attend school. She makes liquid soap from home on retail basis.  She is requested for a loan of 500,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy materials to make soap. She gets additional income from selling used clothes . Her goal and aspiration is to open a soap-making factory in future.  She works seven days a week . Her major business challenges include price fluctuations to buy her materials. She lives in a rented house with access to electricity and piped water . Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy materials for making soap

loans.name: Gerasim

texts.en: Gerasim is 56 years old and he lives in Khashtarak frontier village of Tavsuh region. He has large family and he lives with his wife, two sons, daughter-in-law and also grandchildren. His elder son lives and works in Yerevan city. Gerasim has higher education and specialty of engineer. In his family all his three sons have higher pedagogical education and all of them work of their specialty. Many years Gerasim worked at the village school as a teacher of mathematics and started from 2003 he became the director of the same school. All the family also finds time to be engaged in farming. In his farm Gerasim has cows, pigs, piglets, bee hives and also chickens. With the help of his large family Gerasim arranges the sale of his farm products such as milk, meat, honey and eggs. From his orchard he also sells apple, persimmon and nuts.  As he mentions for his large family to develop farming is greatly profitable since it is good way of providing fresh products for his family and also it brings not small income for their daily needs. With this loan Gerasim will surely develop his farming especially his cattle breeding; with this loan of 500.000 Armenian drams he wants to buy two bulls and also a lot of fodder for his all farm cattle.

loans.use: to buy two bulls and also a lot of fodder for his all farm cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Joyce would like to buy animal feeds for her dairy animals.

loans.name: Gabriela De Los Ánge

texts.en:
Gabriela began selling cosmetics because of her family’s economic need and also because she enjoys sales. Gabriela is married and has one 12 year-old son and one10 year-old daughter. Her husband is a waiter, however his salary isn’t enough to cover all the family’s expenses. Therefore, Gabriela began her sales two years ago. In order to cover the orders from her clients and to offer better service, Gabriela needs a loan in the amount of $250, which she will use toward those ends.

It has been difficult for Gabriela and her family to overcome obstacles to her children having a better education and a better life, but Gabriela is willing to work harder for this each day. Your generosity could be of great help to this family, and they would be very grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La necesidad económica de la familia y el gusto por las ventas hicieron que Gabriela se dedicara a la venta de cosméticos, ella es casada y tiene un hijo de 12 años y una hija de 10. Su esposo es mesero, sin embargo, el salario que recibe no alcanza a cubrir todos los gastos de su familia y hace dos años Gabriela comenzó con las ventas. Para cubrir los pedidos de sus clientes y ofrecer un mejor servicio Gabriela necesita un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 250 dólares que utilizará con este fin.

Ha sido difícil para Gabriela y su familia superar todos los obstáculos para que sus hijas puedan tener una buena educación y una mejor vida, pero Gabriela está dispuesta a seguir esforzándose cada día más. Tú generosidad puede ser de gran ayuda para esta familia, ellos te lo agradecerán.

loans.use: To buy stock of cosmetics

loans.name: Siti

texts.en: Siti A. is a 35 year old mother and is married with two children, all of whom are boys.  Her husband, Anda, is a fisherman who earns about $4 a day. To supplement her husband's income, Siti A. sells household goods such as rice, vegetables, kerosene and cigarettes.  From this business, she can earn about $100 in a day as an income.  Siti A. needs a loan of $100. With this loan she can buy more goods to sell, thus more or less double her income. She really wants to have more income for her children's education and to give them a better life than she grew up with. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of one year.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 65 years old. She is a widow. She has 6 children. 3 of her children are still in school. Grace joined Olokiret women group after the group chairlady explained to her of the need of the women joining hands so as to solve some of the community problems. Like her colleagues, Grace has planted trees and is happy to be a member of Olokiret women group. Grace has this to say of the group…” before this groups came up, one could keep her problems to herself. Now we work together and we are able to come up with solutions to some of the problems.” When the group decided to buy steers for grazing, Grace was very happy. She says this..” I have only 2 steers. If I can get some more, I would be very happy. I will look forward to a better future after a few months.” Grace has applied for USD 750. This will go to buy 6 steers. She will graze them for 8 months after which she will sell and pay the loan in lump sum. The profits will be used to buy steers. She plans to increase the herd she grazes per period.

loans.use: Grace intends to buy Steers

loans.name: Noviyanti

texts.en: Noviyanti is 25 years old and is married, with 1 child aged 4. Selling snacks is Noviyanti's business to supplement her family's income, usually earning $16 per day. Her husband, Heri, is a mechanic. Noviyanti is a member of MBK and asks for a $100 loan to expand her shop. The remainder will be used to improve her husband's business. She willing to repay this loan within the loan period.

loans.use: To expand her shop and increase her husband's business

loans.name: Gladis Bertha

texts.es:
With a lot of effort and the help of her husband and sons, Gladys has been able to open a small shop in the city of Lima to which she dedicates a great deal of her time. With everybody helping, there is also time to harvest the crops on their small parcels of land which brings in extra income. Even with a few steady income streams, the money is not enough to cover the costs for medical treatment as she and her husband get older. Because of this, Gladys is requesting a loan to expand the products she offers and grow her business, helping them reach their goals and improve their quality of life.

Gladis ha podido abrir con mucho esfuerzo y ayuda de su querido esposo una pequeña bodega en la ciudad de Lima, a que le dedican gran parte de su tiempo. Para llevar las riendas de su negocio cuentan con el importante apoyo de sus queridos hijos y esto les da tiempo para continuar con la siembra de productos en sus parcelas de tierras a fin de obtener un ingreso adicional.A pesar de tener algunos ingresos muy sólidos, este dinero es insuficiente para solventar los gastos que genera su tratamiento médico, por el sinnúmero de dolencias que los aquejan por la avanzada edad que poseen.Ha consecuencia de este hecho, Gladys, tiene pensado mejorar sus productos y su negocio. Solicita un préstamo y apela a tu bondadoso corazón para acumular la suma que requiere con el objetivo de poner en marcha sus anhelos.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: THE LOAN WILL BE USE TO HELP GROW THEIR BUSINESS, AND GENERATE MORE INCOME TO COVER MEDICAL EXPENSES.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es:
Esperanza is a retailer and owns the Bazar bookstore on Buenos Aires Avenue in the city of La Paz. She has a daughter who is studying at the state university and also helps Esperanza at the bookstore. This activity is Esperanza´s main source of income with which she supports herself and her daughter. They live in the Villa Nueva Potosí area of La Paz.

The credit she requests through Kiva will be used to buy merchandise (toys) for the year-end holidays, and in this way she´ll be able to continue with the store sales (Bazar bookstore).

This is her fourth credit with IMPRO; an evaluation was done to qualify her for the loan. She has been a client of IMPRO since 2003 and is considered an excellent client.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Esperanza es comerciante y tiene una Librería Bazar en la Av. Buenos Aires de la ciudad de La Paz, tiene una hija que esta postulando a la Universidad estatal y al mismo tiempo ayuda a Esperanza en la librería. Esta actividad es su principal fuente de ingreso con que Esperanza y su hija se mantienen; vive en la Zona de Villa Nueva Potosí de la Ciudad de La Paz.

El crédito que solicita a través de Kiva lo destinara para la compra de mercadería (juguetes) por las fiestas de fin de año, de esa forma podrá continuar con las ventas de tienda (librería-Bazar).

Es el cuarto crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo. Ella es cliente de IMPRO desde el año 2003 y es considerada un excelente cliente.

loans.use: Purchase toys to sell during year-end holidays.

loans.name: Muk Yemusumba B Group

texts.en:
Rita is 33 years old and married with three children. She offers tailoring services. She intends to use the extra business profits to pay school fees for her children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing machines

loans.name: Mohamed Baufelloh

texts.en: Mohamed J. is 47 years old and married with 9 children.  He lives in Dogolia village of Koinadugu, Sierra Leone.  Mohamed buys and sells cows, and also keeps some for the family milk.  With his previous loans, he purchased a cow twice a week and sold them in Freetown.  Mohamed says that the previous loan enabled him to continue to raise his family cow until maturity for production.  He is requesting $1200.00 to enable him to purchase 3 cows at once, twice a month and make a good  profit.

loans.use: To purchase and sell cattle.

loans.name: Gulom

texts.en:
Turdimurotov Gulom is 26 years old. He is married and has an adorable 2-year-old son.

Gulom raises and sells cattle. After purchasing the cattle in the local market, he raises them at home. Four years ago, when Gulom made the decision to raise cattle, he constructed a cow shed. Now he has four cows to sell for $2,000 USD. The business is stable and generates the main income for the family, allowing Gulom to improve their living conditions.

Now Gulom is planning to purchase one more cow. For this purpose, he requests 2000.00 Somoni ($600.00 USD). For this first loan, Gulom is grateful to all for trusting and supporting him, and he promises to pay back the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy a cow to raise and sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. is a trader who owns a provision store. She is married and has two children. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the family’s financial needs. She is working very hard to support her husband in meeting the family’s expenses. She wants to increase her income.

She is asking for $525.00 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more goods for resale

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 32 year old butcher, who is married with four children. He and his one worker have been working in his butcher shop for 9 years. He buys a cow from the abattoir every couple of days for $235, sells half of it straight away for $135 to another butcher making him $18. The other half he takes back to his shop and butchers the meat to sell by the kilo. Aside from the head, which he leaves at the abattoir, he sells every part of the cow. He makes around $30 profit on the second half of the cow.

He is looking for a loan of $600 to buy some new scales, new machetes and to help him buy a fresh cow as he has recently used his profits to pay for the children's school fees.

loans.use: Moses is looking for a loan to use in his butcher business.  He wants to by some new scales, new machetes and to help him buy a fresh cow as he has recently used his profits to pay for the children's school fees.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita is a responsible and caring mother who maintains her family through her activity as a farmer, producing crops such as potatoes, corn, etc. This activity has helped her to provide for the costs of raising her family. To earn money for a loaf of bread, Margarita spends days in her fields working to ensure that her products are competitive in the marketplace. To do this, she requires both fertilizers and fumigation of her crops and because of the high price of these products and her lack of funds it is difficult for her to acquire these necessary tools. She therefore asks your help to acquire these products which will improve her harvests and, most importantly, protect the crops from a variety of illnesses.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski and Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteers. Description corrected by Daniel Kahn, Kiva staff

MARGARITA, es una madre responsable y cariñosa y su forma de mantener a su familia es a través de su actividad como agricultora produciendo productos agrícolas como: papa, maíz, etc. Esta actividad le ayuda hasta el día de hoy a solventar los gastos de su familia.Margarita para poder llevar un pan a su hogar tiene que pasar días enteros trabajando en sus chacras para que sus productos sean competitivos en el mercado y para ello es necesario las fumigaciones y proveerles de los abonos necesarios a sus cultivos y es por falta de dinero que no puede acceder a estos productos por sus altos costos y requiere de su ayuda para poder adquirirlos y así mejorar y cuidar sus sembríos y sobre todo protegerlos de las diversas enfermedades que tienen los productos

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia posesses a great talent for creating beautiful woven works such as, hats, jackets and gloves for children, women, and men. She started more than 11 years ago when she decided to leave her home village of Lampa, and root her family in the city of Juliaca.

After seeing that the income of her husband, Mario, as a master bricklayer was insufficient to cover the costs of the home, Julia decided to create her own source of income. She appropriated a small area in her little house to create a weaving workshop. Thanks to her beautiful works she has a large quantity of orders, orders that she cannot fill right now due to lack of raw materials (wool). For this purpose Julia is requesting a loan and hopes to touch your generous hearts that you may be willing to contribute to her work.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer.

Julia posee gran talento para realizar bellos trabajos tejidos, tales como: chompas, chalecos y guantes para niños, caballeros y damas. Empezó hace más D. 11 años cuando decidió salir D. su pueblo natal Lampa y radicar junto a su querida familia en la ciudad D. Juliaca. Julia, al ver que los ingresos que su esposo Mario obtenía con su labor D. maestro albañil era insuficiente para cubrir los gastos D. su hogar, decidió crear su propia fuente D. ingreso económico.Para ello adecuó un pequeño espacio D. su pequeña casa e instaló su taller D. tejido, gracias a los hermosos trabajos que realiza logró contar con gran cantidad D. solicitudes, solicitudes que en estos momentos no pueD. cumplir por la falta D. materia prima (lana), con ese propósito Julia se presenta y espera tocar corazones generosos que estén dispuestos a colaborar con su labor.

loans.use: Purchase of raw material for weaving and to complete client order that are currently pending because she does not have wool.

loans.name: Hacia Adelante Group

texts.en:
Antonia M. belongs to the Hacia Adelante Bank of Hope and lives in a small community on the outskirts of San Pedro de Macorís. She lives in small home with her husband and five children, whose ages range from 6 to 16 years of age.

Antonia has a small 'fritura' business where she offers a variety of fried foods to her community. This most often includes fried plantain chips, fried pork, and other fried meats or starchy vegetables. She used her loan to buy a bigger variety of food to cook and to also buy her cooking oil in bulk to reduce costs.

Her dream is to have her own large food business where she owns her own location and building to sell it from. As she works towards that dream, she has created a goal to simply maintain a steady flow of business, to make sure that things are stable in her house, and to slowly grow her business.

Antonia and her story represent the Hacia Adelante Bank of Hope; she belongs to a group of 10 men and women who work hard to improve their lives through the help of their small loans.  Each of these men and women has taken out a similar loan to that of Antonia's. On behalf of all of them, and our team here at Esperanza, thank you for your support!

loans.use: To  invest in more merchandise such as vegetables and meats to fry and sell to her community members.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is a 31-year-old entrepreneur and the mother of 1 school-aged child. She lives in Mombasa, Kenya. She began her current business of selling dressmaking materials in 1999. She frequently travels to Nairobi to purchase stock at wholesale prices. The prime location of her business on a busy street, her 3 years of experience there, and her friendly interaction with customers have all enabled her to establish a good client base. Monica plans to expand her business with her next loan of US$800.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Mr. Net Sopheak's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Net S. is the group leader of five loan members who live in Chres Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He is a fisherman and his wife, Mrs. Bork La, is a farmer who cultivates vegetable. They are married without any children. Although they work in different businesses, they still experience poor living conditions. Mr. Net S. is asking for a loan to buy two pigs to start a pig breeding business. He hopes this business will help improve his family's living conditions.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy two pigs to start a pig breeding business.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: K. Moses is a member of Kiwamirembe Group in Kigombya. He has owned and operated a general store for 4 years. He is a married man with two children of whom one is in school.  He plans to see his children have the best education possible through his efforts.  When he started getting loans, life was difficult for him with almost nothing to sell in his shop but now things are better because he is able to care for his family and parents, who live nearby in the village. He was able to buy a plot of land recently and now plans to buy a large piece of land to start a farming business. Moses needs a loan to buy more goods for his shop.

loans.use: Buy more goods for his shop

loans.name: April Joy

texts.en:
April Joy G. is 20 years old; she lives with her partner and their child.  She decided to join ASHI because she wants to start married life with some income-generating activity to finance the needs of the family.  At present they are still living with her parents. They aim to have their own house and have a stable life for their children and for the whole family. 

She repaid her first loan last Nov. 12, 2008, which she used as starting capital for her food-selling business in the village in Bagumbayan, San Jose, Antique. Philippines.

loans.use: Food Vending

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El grupo denominado Nueva Esperanza se conformó en el mes de setiembre del año 2.007.
El origen de la asociación del comité se dio a partir de la motivación de un grupo de amigas, preocupadas por contribuir con la mejoría de la calidad de vida.
Las integrantes del grupo se dedican a distintas actividades comerciales como: venta de frutas, mercería, ropas, comidas, bijouterie, leche, Cds., y a la confección de ropas.
El comité cuenta con una comisión sólida, es un excelente grupo el cual activa continuamente para la recaudación de fondos para solventar alguna eventualidad, se destaca la solidaridad y la comprensión entre ellas.
 Las actividades que desarrollan cada una son:

Eleuteria C.	Venta de mercería
Aparicia R.	Venta de frutas
Catalina R.	Venta de mercería
Nilda F.	Venta de bijouterie
Martina C.	Venta de ropas
Cristina G.	Venta de comidas
Petronila B.	Venta de ropas
María Lourdes C.	Venta de ropas
Leonora Martínez	Venta de mercería
Lilian P.	Venta de ropas
Dionicia Giménez	Venta de leche
Marina R.	Venta de frutas
Alicia Sánchez	Venta de frutas
Blanca Velázquez	Confección de ropas
Artemia C.	Venta de Cds
texts.en:
The group called Nueva Esperanza (New Hope) was formed in September 2007. The group was started as a result of the motivation of a group of friends, who were concerned about contributed to improving their quality of life. The members of the groups pursue different commercial activities like selling fruit, haberdashery, clothes, food, jewelry, milk, and CDs and making clothes. The group has a solid commission. This is an excellent group which is continually active in collecting funds to pay for some possibility cost. This emphasizes the solidarity and understanding among the women.

They each pursue the following activities: Eleuteria C. sells haberdashery Aparicia R. sells fruit Catalina R. sells haberdashery Nilda F. sells jewelry Martina C. sells clothes Cristina G. sells food Petronila B. sells clothes María Lourdes C. sells clothes Leonora Martínez sells haberdashery Lilian P. sells clothes Dionicia Giménez sells milk Marina R. sells fruit Alicia Sánchez sells fruit Blanca Velázquez makes clothes Artemia C. sells CDs

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The members of the group will invest in the purchase of milk; sugar; fruit; clothes; items for the home like pots, jars, cutlery, etc.; CDs. All of these items will then be sold. They will also buy thread and fabric for the production of clothes, among other things.

loans.name: Lonh

texts.en: Mrs. C. is 30 years old and works growing rice in Prolay Thom Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. Her husband, 43, works with Mrs. C., earning revenues around KHR14000 ($3.2). She has two children, two of whom are married and two other are teenagers attending school. To improve her business by alleviating physical labor, C. would like to ask for a loan to purchase two buffaloes to add more labor for farming business.

loans.use: To purchase two buffaloes to add more labor for farming business

loans.name: Edward's Group

texts.en: W. Edward is a member of Kigalama group in Mityana. He is a hard working and devoted man with a bar as his business. He sells all sorts of beers and spirits including local brew for his customers in Kigalama T.C. He has been in this business for 8 years and is grateful that he is and has always been able to operate his bar with the help of loans. In addition, he is also a farmer with gardens that he usually manages in the morning hours while the bar mainly booms in the evenings and afternoons. He has been able to buy himself a plot of land out of his accumulated savings and this time round, he seeks a loan to help with buying beers, sodas, wines and local brew for his bar.

loans.use: Buying more beers, sodas, wines and local brew for his bar.

loans.name: Vith

texts.en: Mr. Vith R. was born in 1943 and now lives in Traing Roka village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land in which he cultivates rice for a living. He faces a small problem because the soil in his field is infertile, so he is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. He will use some of the loan to buy pesticides to kill insects affecting his field. His wife, Mrs. Sim Khet, shown in the left in the photo, and their child help Mr. Vith R. in his farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to make his rice field fertile and pesticides to protect it from insects.

loans.name: Laloata

texts.en: A. Vili, 39, is married with one child.  She has one year of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers five days per week. This is her first loan with Kiva's partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145).  SPBD loans are A.’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase taro tops, knives, a spade and barred fence

loans.name: Fowzya Group

texts.en:
Fowzya G. is the group leader of the Fowzya group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for his/her own business.

Fowzya wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of fresh fruit products.  He wants to buy the necessary materials for his business.  BIbi Ahfeyza wants to take a loan for her business of quilt making. She wants to expand her business. Hamid khan wants to take a loan for his general store. He wants to make his shop larger. They are very happy with these loans to Afghanistan.
 
They want to say that these loans are very useful because they can provide a good chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses and become stronger in business and in life. This group appreciates this loan process  in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To enlarge their businesses

loans.name: Chhouk

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhouk T., 39, has been a local farmer for more than five years. She grows two types of crops: rice and vegetables, and she can plant twice a year. Usually she harvests and sells to buyers monthly. Her husband works with her in the business and they have seven children. All their children are students who always help with the crops when they are not going to school.
During the rainy season, T. lacks capital for the upcoming rice farming season. Thus, she has decided to seek a loan in order to buy seeds to begin planting crops.
T.'s husband is pictured.

loans.use: To buy seeds to begin planting rice

loans.name: Rohat

texts.ru: Рохат Исобоева в месяц несколько раз ездит за товар в Истаравшан. Дорога трудная и долгая. У нее есть подруги и попутчики в дороге.  Раньше она сидела на улице и торговала , иногда ее прогоняли из-за отсутствия необходымых документов, а для этого нужно внести необходимую сумму. Или арендовать помещение или магази. Обратилась в Микроинвст , получила кредит  и арендовала небольшой участок , для  торговли. Где она может спокойно продавать.
texts.en:
Rohat I. travels to Istaravshan several times a month to buy goods. The road is long and not good. She has friends and companions on it. She used to sit on the street and sell, and sometimes be sent away because she lacked the right documents. She needed to either pay the set price or rent a stall or store. She turned to Microinvest, received a loan, and began renting a small space for sales where she can work in peace.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales turnover

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia B. is a 66 year-old woman who hails from the beautiful land of Antipolo City, the capital city of Rizal province in the Philippines. Her husband died years ago and left her with a daughter, Dina, who is now 43 years old and a college graduate. Lilia is a member of the Rizalwest Branch of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines.

Considering her age, Lilia has invested the money from her loans in a general store in her village. The business brings her enough income for her day-today living. She is now requesting a loan amounting for 15,000 pesos for additional capital for her store.

She dreams of helping her grandchildren with their school expenses with savings from her business. She also still dreams that someday her general store will grow and become a grocery store.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store.

loans.name: Davaadorj

texts.en:
Davaadorj T., a 37-year-old married woman with three children, all attending a local elementary school, lives in Arhangay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. Since 2002 Davaadorj has been running a souvenir and toy stall at the local market. She started her business by travelling to Ereen, a Chinese border city, to purchase a variety of toys for 300,000 tugrugs, and as a result of her hard work, her retail sales business has expanded. Now her working capital has reached 4,000,000 tugrugs (equal to $2,800 USD).

Her husband, Lhagva-Otgon, an electrician, helps her business when he has time, and Davaadorj's hope is to eventually open her own toy and souvenir store. She is requesting a loan to purchase more toys and souvenir items from Ereen, China.

loans.use: To purchase toys and souvenirs.

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Мархабо молодая женщина , которая продаёт детскую одежду в магазине на рынке Худжанда. За товаром она ездит сама в город Бишкек., раз в месяц. Она хочет на следующий кредит съездить за товаром и привезти школьный ассортимент товаров для девочек и мальчиков. Мархабо благодарна инвесторам за финансирование.
texts.en:
Marhabo is a young woman, who sells children’s clothing at a store at the Khujand market. She travels for the merchandise herself to the city of Bishkek once per month. She wants to use her next loan to travel for the merchandise and bring an assortment of school goods for girls and boys. Marhabo is grateful to investors for the financing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of children's school goods

loans.name: Lorna Awuor

texts.en:
Lorna is 23 years old, and she runs a small shop that sells basic goods like bread, soap, salt, and sugar. Lorna buys the products from a wholesaler in town and sells them near her home in Nyamasaria. She will use the loan to expand the room in which she is selling goods; she will also buy a larger variety of products to sell.

Lorna is well-educated; she finished high school, and hopes to save up enough money to go to university part-time for accounting. She is an unwed single mom who supports her daughter as well as her three younger siblings.

Lorna wants to open a health support group in her area, because she believes that the people in her community don’t know how to help each other. She is a community health worker already, and someday hopes to be able to expand her influence to help more sick people in her community.

K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional micro-finance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. Many of the loan recipients from this organization are volunteer community healthcare workers like Lorna. For more information about K-MET, see the partner link on the lower right side of this webpage.

video.title: Kiva Entrepreneur Lorna Awuor from  Kenya

loans.use: Renovations and more supplies

loans.name: Juana Pastora

texts.es:
La señora Juana es socia del Banco Comunal “Diana de Gales”, en el distrito de Puno, provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno, ella tiene 40 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente y madre de 02 hijos. Tiene estudios de educación secundaria completa.  Vive en el Barrio Cesar Vallejo.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 9 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, monto que le sirvió como capital para su negocio de compra-venta de productos de la región.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional de S/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, el préstamo le servirá para poder comprar papas, chuños, quinua, tuntas, además comprará carnes, queso, miel de abeja. Ella solo atiende pedidos, realiza sus compras en Tiquillaca, Atuncolla, y vende en Puno y Juliaca, también se dedica a su negocio de venta de joyas.

Su deseo es poder comprar un puesto para vender en el mercado de Puno.

A ella le gustan las facilidades en los préstamos  y las reuniones.
texts.en:
Sra. Juana is a member of the Communal Bank “Diana de Gales”, located in the District of Puno, Puno Province, Department of Puno. She is 40 years old, in a common law marriage, and the mother of 2 children. Sra. Juana completed her high school education and lives in the neighborhood of Cesar Vallejo. She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 9 years. Her first loan in the amount of 500 soles was used as capital for her business of buying and selling regional products. Sra. Juana is now requesting another loan of 3000 soles to buy potatoes, potato flour, quinoa, and dehydrated potatoes. She will also buy meat, cheese, and honey. Sra. Juana places her orders and purchases her merchandise in Tiquillaca and Atuncolla. She then sells her products in Puno and Juliaca. In addition, she operates a business selling jewelry. Sra. Juana hopes to buy a vending post at the Puno market. She enjoys the simplicity of her loans and the Communal Bank meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes, potato flour, dehydrated potatoes, quinoa, meat, cheese, and honey

loans.name: Talalelei

texts.en: Talalelei L. (0) is a 48-year-old woman living in the town of Taufusi. She is married and has eight school-aged children. Talalelei owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling baked goods in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 450 WST a month. Talalelei joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,200 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Talalelei is now requesting a new loan of 1,950 WST which will again be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. The loan will be her 3rd from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Accroître la taille de son commerce

loans.name: Yajaira

texts.en:
Yajaira is an associate of Esperanza living in the community of Quinientos in the Province of El-Seybo. The area where she lives is economically based around agriculture and services such as running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. She lives in her community in a home with her husband and her two month old son. She is described as being entrepreneurial and hardworking.

Yajaira has been very successful in the Esperanza program and she is taking out her first individual loan, having successfully completed several group loans. She will use this loan to improve her business by painting the building where it is located, purchasing a new basin to wash hair in, and purchasing more beauty products to sell to her clients. She has over two years of experience in this business, has recieved training in beauty school, and has been so succesful that she has had to hire two employees to help her in her salon. Her long term goal is to continue developing her salon by adding features such as pedicures and manicures, so that it will be a full service salon and provide income to support her child. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Beauty products, wash basin and paint for her shop

loans.name: Dolor

texts.en:
26-year-old Dolor M. lives with her husband Crisanto, a restaurant employee, and their only child, in Malibay, Pasay City.
 
Dolor has been working hard on her piggery business.  She raises pigs to get income to support her family. She also sells fresh pork meat.  She brings her pigs to the butcher when they are ready for slaughtering.  She also finds time to manage a rickshaw (pedicab) operation.  All these business activities account for her monthly income of P24,000.00.

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2001.  She has a pending application for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of P30,000.00 to infuse fresh capital into her business.
 
Dolor hopes to add a canteen business to her existing ones.  She also wants to have a meat stall in the nearby public market.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to infuse fresh capital into her business

loans.name: Nghiêm's Group

texts.en:
Quý Nghiêm Thị (20201070014) is a 49-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Quý is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Trung Bạn 02 (2).


Quý is married and has three adult children.  To making a living, Quý sells animal feed & farm-related products in the local community.  Quý has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5.600.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, Quý joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Quý has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 7.392.000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Quý from SEDA.  Quý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn V. M. (20201070015) is a 27-year-old male who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support his recycling services business.


2.  Nguyễn K. N. (20201070016) is a 39-year-old male who is requesting a 4.256.000 VND loan to support his fishing business.


3.  Trương Thị D. (20201070017) is a 27-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070018) is a 60-year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (2020010719) is a 28-year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business making furniture. 

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Quý Nghiêm Thị (20201070014) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Quý là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Trung Bạn 02 (2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm thức ăn gia súc & có liên quan đến nông trại trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Quý thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 12 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Quý kiếm được khoảng 5.600.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Quý đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Quý đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn V. M. (20201070015) là 27 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ tái chế.


2.  Nguyễn K. N. (20201070016) là 39 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  Trương Thị D. (20201070017) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070018) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (2020010719) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aïssétou

texts.fr: M. Aïssétou est née en 1953 à Djougou au Nord du Bénin. Mariée à BAGRI Kora, un agent de la mairie de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, Aïssétou est mère de sept enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Aïssétou vit avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Kowégbo à Cotonou, depuis douze ans. Aïssétou vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Aïssétou vend des condiments de sauce (tomate, oignons, piments, etc.), de l’huile d’arachide, et également du maïs à son domicile. Aïssétou a déjà 10 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Aïssétou s’approvisionne. Aïssétou est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits antérieurs et qui ont été bien remboursés. C’est pour renforcer son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle que Aïssétou sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
M. Aïssétou was born in 1953 in Djougou in northern Benin.  Married to BAGRI Kora, a representative of the townhall of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, she is the mother of seven children who are all in school.  For 12 years, she has been living with her children and husband in the Houéyiho district in Cotonou.  She comes to her husband's aid in meeting family expenses.  To address her needs, Aïssétou sells sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers, etc.), peanut oil, and also corn out of her home.  She already has ten years of experience in this domain.  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she stock up.  She is a previous ALIDé client, having already benefited from three past loans, which were repaid.  To bolster her business and to satisfy her customers further, she's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sauce condiments, drums of peanut oil, and sacks of corn

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les huit  membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne  47 ans, 5 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de tasses, fruits, graines de néré, tissus, céréales (graine de riz, maïs, mil, sorgho etc), viandes etc. 
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 6 douzaines de tasses, 6 régimes de bananes, 1chargement de charrette d’oranges et de mandarines, 4 sacs de graines de néré pour faire du sounbala, 4 douzaines de complets (tissus pour hommes et femmes), 12 sacs de céréales (riz,maïs, sorgho, mil), 5 petits ruminants (pour vendre leur viande le jour de foire)  et 7paquets de condiments alimentaires.  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Mamassoni,  de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant, en détail et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 37.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Kotognogontala group are mainly married women with an average age of 47, and an average of five children. They generally live in polygamous families in Bougoula Hameau, a village in the Sikasso municipality, the third largest administrative region in Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation in order to meet the demands of their customers, and are on their sixth loan. Their previous loans have been successfully repaid. They sell cups, fruit, néré seeds, fabric, cereals (rice, maize, millet, sorgho etc), meat etc. With their new loan they intend to buy six dozen cups, six bunches of bananas, one cartload of oranges and mandarins, four bags of néré seeds to make sounbala, four dozen suits (fabric for men or women), five small ruminants (so that the meat may be sold on market days) and seven packets of condiments. They source their goods from the Sikasso town market and from neighbouring villages, and sell their wares at the Mamassoni market, through home visits, and from their own homes. Their sales are cash- or credit-based, and their customers are both men and women. The women envisage making an average monthly profit of 37.500 FCFA each; part of this will be used for savings and family needs, and the rest reinvested in business activities.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pagnes

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida A., 55, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Nestor Ogaro, they are blessed with 10 children, five of whom are already working. Having a big family, both of them make sure that they earn enough for their family’s basic needs.  She and her husband have been managing her own variety store for more than 14 years.

Adelaida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than seven years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used all the money she borrowed to buy added stocks in her variety store.   Her business lets her earn a net profit of 9,000 Philippine pesos (about $197 US) per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to get a loan of 24,000 pesos. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying additional stocks for her store.

She dreams that her three children who are still studying can ultimately graduate from college so that they too can have a better life.   

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Increasing store inventory

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel V., 29, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Roy V., a tricycle driver, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been direct selling different cosmetics and branded women’s clothes for more than a year.

Raquel has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), a Kiva partner, for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy more cosmetic and apparel products for resale. Her business lets her earn an extra profit of 7,600 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital by buying more clothes and assorted cosmetic products as added stock for her direct-selling business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finance her children's education until they graduate from college. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying more clothes and assorted cosmetic products as added stock for her direct-selling business

loans.name: Norelyn

texts.en:
Norelyn M., age 50, is making sure that her family has enough to meet their daily needs. She is married to Joel M., and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure to help her husband earn, so that their family can have a better life. She has been direct selling branded beauty products and apparel for quite some time.

Norelyn has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT's Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues, because she has used the money she borrowed to continue her direct selling business.

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for an 8000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, allowing her to place advance orders for her direct selling line.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and that she will be able to finish schooling of her children.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To allow her to place advance orders for her direct selling line

loans.name: We Believe Weself Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs named their group 'We Believe Weself'. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve their families’ well-being. 

Memunatu K., pictured on the right, is the leader of this group. Memunatu was born in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. The 32-year-old is married to a teacher and they have 3 children who are attending primary school. For many years now, Memunatu has been selling gara lappers (locally dyed cloth). With her share of the loan, she will buy working materials like white cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder and pay experts to make designs on the white cotton.

loans.use: Buy working materials like white cotton, inks, caustic soda, etc. and pay experts to make designs

loans.name: Sreyroth

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreyroth S. (pictured with her children), age 39, and her husband, Mr. Sopheap I, age 41, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married for 16 years and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of them are still young.  

Sreyroth has been a silk weaver since she was young, a skill she learned from her mother. Her husband is a construction worker. He works in his village. In addition, Sreyroth hopes to create another new business, selling lotus, but she doesn’t have enough capital. So she is requesting a loan of 500 USD to help her to purchase lotus under contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase lotus under contract for resale.

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 49 years old and is married with four children: two boys and two girls. They live in Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone. Her first child is working; two are drivers and the last child is in school.

Dora sells fish and has been a LAPO, SL client for over two years.  She has taken out four previous loans and bought a van to transport her fish.

Dora wants a loan of 3,000,000 Leones to buy more fish and she intends to live a good life.

loans.use: Buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is a widow with five boys and three girls. Five of her children attend school. Selina sells charcoal and wants to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal with the Ksh.15,000 loan. She has been in this business for five years and was previously selling fish. Her other source of income is from selling vegetables door-to-door and from rental housing. Her customers are mainly her neighbors. 

The main challenge to her business is that there are so many people who sell charcoal that there is a lot of competition. Selina owns her home but has no piped water or electricity. Her greatest expenses are food and school fees. She hopes that in two or three years she will have renovated her rental house and that she will lead a happy life.

loans.use: 10 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Mayranush

texts.en: Mayranush S. lives in Sevan city. She is 46 years old. She lives with her husband and three sons. Mayranush is a commodity expert, but she worked as a cook for about five years and then as a shop assistant. In 2002, she organized her own business. Mayranush's business consists of clothes trading, which she manages in a rented place at Sevan Fair. Mayranush has borrowed eight loans from Nor Horizon and now she is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy spring and summer clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy spring and summer clothes for her business

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia, a resident of Borewala (which is famous for its shrines) Pakistan, is the wife of M. A. and the mother of five children. All of them are enrolled in a school and are getting an education. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over fifteen years.

A very caring and loving lady, Safia operates a cart making (weaving a cart frame with rope) business. Her business provides major support to her family. She fills carts on order and receives income which she uses to pay for the utilities and for the education expenses of her kids.
 
Her husband is involved in a rice selling business. He purchases the rice sacks from the market and supplies them to the grocery shops and generates income.

Safia has completed two loans from Asasah and now is applying for the third time to invest the capital in her husband’s business so he can purchase the rice sacks and expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase rice sacks to sell

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr: S. Rachelle est née le 22 Mars 1970 et vit depuis quinze ans environs au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à BODEHOUSSE Casmir, un enseignant, Rachelle est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Rachelle vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants à Sènadé. Le couple se partage les différentes charges du foyer. Rachelle a arrêté l'école à l'université. Il y a environs huit ans que Rachelle a commencé la vente de produits divers (conserves de tomate et de sardine, riz, huile d'arachide, papiers hygiéniques, arachides grillés, etc.) à son domicile. Rachelle s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Rachelle désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Rachelle sollicite un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Rachelle S. was born 22 March 1970, and has been living about 15 years in the Sènadé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Casmir BODEHOUSSE, a teacher, Rachelle is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. She lives with her husband and children in Sènadé. The couple shares the various household expenses. Rachelle stopped attending school at university level. About eight years ago she began selling various products (canned tomatoes and sardines, rice, peanut oil, toilet paper, roasted peanuts, etc.) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Rachelle is a former client of ALIDé, having already been granted three loans, all fully reimbursed. She wants to increase her stock supply and better respond to customer demand, which is why she is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products (rice, canned tomatoes and sardines, pasta, etc.), and peanut oil containers.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is widowed with six children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of her late brothers children.  

She owns a retail shop in Mulago selling all types of merchandise. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of mineral water, boxes of Safi (a skin tonic), cartons of salt and loaves of bread. Winnie has been in this business for six years.  She buys this merchandise from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala. She uses public transport to and from shopping and goes for shopping once a week.   She works six days a week. 

Winnie wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling on a wholesale basis only and also to buy a plot of land. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged.  She rents and resides in a two-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of Safi, mineral warer and loaves of bread.

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Cette dame est une femme mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de agoé fiovi, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbon de bois, une partie de son stock a été détruite par les pluies de ces derniers jours, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 20 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This lady is a married woman and the mother of three children. She lives with her family in the Agoé Fiovi district. She has a revenue-generating business involving charcoal. Part of her stock has been destroyed by the rains of recent days. She would like to stock up again. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying 20 sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal

loans.name: Mayra

texts.es:
Mayra P. M. es una  señora  de 45  años de edad quien vive con 2 de sus 3 hijos  en una comunidad llamada La fuente  de Santa Teresita de Turrialba, Provincia de Cartago.  Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías.
Doña Mayra tiene 5 años de ganarse la vida rentando sus apartamentos a estudiantes de la zona de Turrialba. Esto le ha permitido tener una fuente de ingresos con la cual ha sacado adelante a sus hijos, y está muy orgullosa  que también gracias a eso hoy  dos de ellos están estudiando en la universidad.
Sin embargo uno de sus apartamentos se encuentra en muy mal estado, y necesita repararlo para seguir rentarlo y seguir obteniendo ganancias, es por eso que necesita un préstamo de ¢350.000 (Trescientos cincuenta    mil colones) para la reparar la instalación eléctrica de un apartamento y arreglar otros detalles que le hacen falta para ser utilizado.
Doña Mayra  es socia de la ECC La Fuente Agrícola Empresarial, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su Primer  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico.
texts.en:
Mayra P. M. is a 45 year old woman who lives with two of her three children in a community called “La Fuente de Santa Teresita de Turrialba,” in the province of Cartago. The population there produces milk and grows coffee. The terrain is irregular and much of it is tropical forest. The community has very picturesque landscapes which combine the tropical forest with two beautiful lakes, coffee plantations, and dairy farms. For the past five years, Ms. Mayra has been making a living renting out her apartments to students within the Turrialba zone. This has provided her with a source of income that has helped her to move her children ahead and she is very proud that two of them study at university. Never the less, one of her apartments is in bad condition and she needs to repair it so that she can continue renting it and earning income. She needs a loan of 3,500,000 CRC ($700) in order to make repairs to the electrical wiring and to other areas, so that the apartment can be used. Ms. Mayra is part of the “La Fuente Agricola Empresarial” communal bank, one of the 100 organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan and she hopes that it will allow her to continue to improve her personal and economic level.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Appartment repairs

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard has been farming in the town of Litein, Rift Valley, Kenya, for the last 10 years. He employs two people from his community. His main products are bananas, avocados, tea and milk which he sells locally. He also operates a hotel and a butchery in the same area. His biggest challenge has been lack of enough knowledge about dairy farming.

Richard has requested a loan of of 50,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will enable him to manage his farming activities and pay school fees for his children. 

Richard is 37 years old. He is married and has been blessed with two children, ages 11 and 14. Both children attend school. Richard is working hard to increase his number of quality dairy cows to five in the next 5 years. He is grateful to Juhudi for the support of the loans being granted to him.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda D. is a 41-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Prk. Paliya, Brgy. Busogon, San Remegio, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She earns an average monthly income of PHP 6000. 

Erlinda is now borrowing PHP 15000 to purchase more stock for her general store. This will be her 5th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Erlinda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: purchase of more stock to sell

loans.name: Honorata

texts.en:
Honorata E. is from the village of Poblacion 2, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 70 years old and is widowed with two adult children. Honorata owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products like shoes and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Honorata joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Honorata is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her seventh from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.
